repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This PR introduces support of initialising const variables with value. Currently only global variables are supported.

I think it partially closes #4014

comment_data.body:
Does it make sense to allow setting a constant value after it's declaration?
C does not allow it and it just seems wrong to allow something like this:
```cython
cdef const int X

cdef function():
    # with a lot
    # of code
    # inside

X = 3
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,29 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cdef const int int_constant = 50
+cdef const int int_constant2 = int_constant
+cdef const int int_constant3
+int_constant3 = 5

comment_data.body: The same goes for an uninitialized constants
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,29 @@
+# mode: run
+
+cdef const int int_constant = 50
+cdef const int int_constant2 = int_constant
+cdef const int int_constant3
+int_constant3 = 5

comment_data.body:
> Does it make sense to allow setting a constant value after it's declaration?

No it does not but I was not able to restrict it in the code. Currently, (if I am not wrong) it is not possible to check in the code whether is assignment part of declaration or not so I am not even trying to do that. I am just ensuring that const variable is assigned at most once.

comment_data.body: I think this is potentially a quite difficult problem. It comes down to the "constant at compile time" vs "constant at runtime" issue. Needs a little more thought (and also a bit of investigation about exactly how C handles it, because it'll affect the C code we need to generate)
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
The other thing worth pointing out here: if you put it into Godbolt you see it's generating a C99 variable length array (which isn't great because it's not C89 compatible, and is also optional after C11).

On C++ it generates a fixed length array though.

Again, I think the solution involves generating enums, but it's obviously a bit fiddly...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,54 @@

+cdef const int int_constant2 = int_constant
+cdef const int int_constant3 = 5
+cdef const int *pint_constant = &int_constant
+cdef const int int_sum_constant = 50 + 50
+# FIXME:
+# cdef const int int_sum_constant = 10 + int_constant
+
+cdef const float float_constant = 50.5
+# FIXME:
+# cdef const float float_sum_constant = 50.2 + 50.3
+# cdef const float float_sum_constant = 50.2 + float_constant

+    >>> test_constant_int_value()
+    50
+    50
+    100
+    """
+    print(int_constant)
+    print(int_constant2)
+    print(int_sum_constant)
+
+def test_array():
+    """
+    >>> test_array()
+    5
+    """
+    cdef int[int_constant3] int_array

comment_data.body:
Appending something in the end risks collisions â€“ however unlikely it is that users call their variables `x` and `x_CONST_VALUE`, it's not impossible and we should be prepared.

Do we really need this C macro?

comment_data.body: This doesn't seem to be tested. Could you explain (or add a comment) why this isn't allowed? It doesn't seem immediately wrong to me if a constant is defined in the module's `.pxd` file. Or is it only about cimported pxd files?

             self.dimension = self.dimension.analyse_const_expression(env)
             if not self.dimension.type.is_int:
                 error(self.dimension.pos, "Array dimension not integer")
-            size = self.dimension.get_constant_c_result_code()
+            size = None
+            if self.dimension.type.is_const:
+                if self.dimension.entry.defined_in_pxd:
+                    error(self.pos, "Array dimension declared in pxd file")

comment_data.body:
> Appending something in the end risks collisions

The infrastracture around generating C code is not final. PR mainly serves as PoC of approach

> Do we really need this C macro?

It is used only to support using `const` values as array dimension see: https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5242#issuecomment-1712574908
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -718,6 +718,12 @@ def generate_type_definitions(self, env, modules, vtab_list, vtabslot_list, code
             self.generate_objstruct_predeclaration(entry.type, code)
         vtabslot_entries = set(vtabslot_list)
         ctuple_names = set()
+        for entry in env.var_entries:
+            type = entry.type
+            cname = entry.cname
+            if entry.type.is_const and entry.init is not None:
+                code.putln("#define %s_CONST_VALUE %s" % (entry.cname.upper(), entry.init))

comment_data.body:
> Could you explain (or add a comment) why this isn't allowed? It doesn't seem immediately wrong to me if a constant is defined in the module's .pxd file.

This error is raised only when `cimport`ed `const` variable is used as array dimension. Array dimensions in C require compile time value, which is not the case of values `cimport`ed.  In `const` variables declared within module this can be circumvented via values declared as macros - see https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5242#issuecomment-1712574908
comment_data.diff_hunk:

             self.dimension = self.dimension.analyse_const_expression(env)
             if not self.dimension.type.is_int:
                 error(self.dimension.pos, "Array dimension not integer")
-            size = self.dimension.get_constant_c_result_code()
+            size = None
+            if self.dimension.type.is_const:
+                if self.dimension.entry.defined_in_pxd:
+                    error(self.pos, "Array dimension declared in pxd file")

comment_data.body:
This test is based on following code: https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/1078cc635c164b594f4eff8c2fdc401412b8f0e7/tests/run/relative_import_leak.srctree#L16-L27

We should build some common infrastructure for it in some near future I suppose.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,70 @@
+PYTHON setup.py build_ext --inplace
+PYTHON -c "import mymodule"
+PYTHON testerr.py
+
+######## setup.py ########
+
+from Cython.Build.Dependencies import cythonize
+from distutils.core import setup
+
+setup(
+  ext_modules = cythonize(["constants.pyx", "mymodule.pyx"]),
+)
+
+######## constants.pxd ########
+
+cdef const int my_c_pyx
+cdef const int my_c_pxd = 6
+
+######## constants.pyx ########
+
+cdef const int my_c_pyx = 5
+
+######## mymodule.pyx ########
+
+cimport constants
+cdef int pyx_c = constants.my_c_pyx
+cdef int pxd_c = constants.my_c_pxd
+assert pyx_c == 5
+assert pxd_c == 6
+
+######## errmodule.pyx ########
+
+cimport constants
+cdef int[constants.my_c_pyx] my_arr
+cdef int[constants.my_c_pxd] my_arr
+
+######## testerr.py ########
+import os
+import sys
+from contextlib import contextmanager
+from Cython.Compiler.Errors import CompileError
+from Cython.Build.Dependencies import cythonize
+
+if sys.version_info[0] < 3:
+    from StringIO import StringIO
+else:
+    from io import StringIO
+
+@contextmanager
+def assert_stderr(expected_errors):

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                    # cimported const value cannot be used since it is run-time value.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -606,7 +606,17 @@ def analyse(self, base_type, env, nonempty=0, visibility=None, in_pxd=False):
             self.dimension = self.dimension.analyse_const_expression(env)
             if not self.dimension.type.is_int:
                 error(self.dimension.pos, "Array dimension not integer")
-            size = self.dimension.get_constant_c_result_code()
+            size = None
+            if self.dimension.type.is_const:
+                if self.dimension.entry.defined_in_pxd:
+                    # Array dimension requires compile-time value.
+                    # cimported const values cannot be used since it is run-time value.

commit.message: Dont use initialisation in the separate line
Error out when array dimension is const
PoC of array dimension from const variable
Use macro only in case variable is not extern
Forbid const variables from .pxd files in array dimension
Add test showing cimporting const variable
